Fig. 7 Separated hydrogenation of DMT under varied reaction temperatures over Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H (a) and Ru/UiO-66 (b). Reaction conditions: 0.1 g catalyst, 2.0 g DMT, 20 mL methanol, 3 MPa H2, 2 h. Fig. 8 Time course of direct upgrading of PET over Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H (a) and Ru/UiO-66 (b). Reaction conditions: 0.1 g catalyst, 2.0 g PET, 20 mL methanol, 160 °C, 3 MPa H2. Fig. 9 Time course (a) and recycle usage (b) of direct upgrading of PET over Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H. Reaction conditions: (a) 0.1 g catalyst, 2.0 g PET, 20 mL methanol, 170 °C, 3 MPa H2; (b) 0.1 g catalyst, 2.0 g PET, 20 mL methanol, 170 °C, 3 MPa H2, 4 h. Article Catalytic upgrading of waste PET to dimethyl cyclohexane-1,4-dicarboxylate over defective sulfonated UiO-66 def -SO3H supported Ru catalyst Weitao Ou a Yingdan Ye a Yibin Zhang a Huaiyuan Zhao a b * Weichen Du a b Zhaoyin Hou a b * a Key Laboratory of Biomass Chemical Engineering of Ministry of Education, Department of Chemistry, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou 310028, Zhejiang, China Key Laboratory of Biomass Chemical Engineering of Ministry of Education Department of Chemistry Zhejiang University Hangzhou Zhejiang 310028 China Key Laboratory of Biomass Chemical Engineering of Ministry of Education, Department of Chemistry, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou 310028, Zhejiang, China b Zhejiang Hengyi Petrochemical Research Institute Co., Ltd., Hangzhou 311200, Zhejiang, China Zhejiang Hengyi Petrochemical Research Institute Co., Ltd. Hangzhou Zhejiang 311200 China Zhejiang Hengyi Petrochemical Research Institute Co., Ltd., Hangzhou 311200, Zhejiang, China * Corresponding author. Poly(ethylene glycol-co-1,4-cyclohexanedimethanol terephthalate) (PETG) possesses excellent properties and stability than traditional poly(ethylene terephthalate) (PET). However, the production and application of PETG are restricted by the expensive monomer (1,4-cyclohexanedimethanol, CHDM). Direct upgrading of waste PET to dimethyl cyclohexane-1,4-dicarboxylate (DMCD) can promote the production of CHDM in large scale. In this work, a bifunctional Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H catalyst was synthesized and utilized in coupled methanolysis (of waste PET to dimethyl terephthalate (DMT)) and hydrogenation (of DMT to DMCD) under mild condition. Characterizations revealed that Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H possessed mesopores (dominant channels of 2.72 and 3.44 nm), enlarged surface area (998 m2·g–1), enhanced acidity (580 μmol·g–1), and Ru nanoparticles (NPs) dispersed highly (45.1%) compared to those of Ru/UiO-66. These combined advantages could accelerate the methanolysis and hydrogenation reactions simultaneously, promoting the performance of direct upgrading of PET to DMCD in one pot. In particular, the conversion of PET and yield of DMCD over Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H reached 100% and 97.7% at 170 °C and 3 MPa H2 within 6 h. Moreover, Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H was also capable for the upcycling of waste PET-based products including beverage bottles, textile fiber and packaging film to DMCD. Graphical Abstract Defective sulfonated UiO-66 def -SO3H supported Ru catalyst was efficient in the direct upgrading of waste polyethylene terephthalate (PET) to dimethyl cyclohexane-1,4-dicarboxylate (DMCD), and the yield of DMCD reached 97.7% at 170 °C within 6 h. Keywords Waste plastic refinery Poly(ethylene terephthalate) Upcycling Dimethyl cyclohexane-1,4- dicarboxylate Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H 1 Introduction Poly(ethylene terephthalate) (PET) has good physical and chemical properties, which is widely used in bottles, fiber and film [1–3]. However, the transparency, ultraviolet shielding, heat resistance and gas barrier properties of traditional PET products are insufficient [4,5]. It was reported that these properties could be achieved by incorporating co-monomer with specific chemical structures, such as 1,4- cyclohexanedimethanol (CHDM) [6,7]. Poly(ethylene glycol-co-1,4-cyclohexanedimethanol terephthalate) (PETG) and poly(1,4-cyclohexylenedimethylene terephthalate glycol) (PCTG) were recommended as alternates of PET since 1980s [8,9], and PETG and PCTG could be synthesized via esterification and/or co-polycondensation of p-phthalic acid (PTA), ethylene glycol, and CHDM [10,11]. After the addition of CHDM, PETG and PCTG show low coloration, good chemical resistance and high toughness [12,13]. Unfortunately, the real production and application of PETG or PCTG are restricted by the high-cost and limited productivity of CHDM [14,15]. Previously, CHDM was synthesized from dimethyl terephthalate (DMT) under harsh conditions using petroleum-based PTA as feedstock in several steps (see routine (a) in Scheme 1 ) [16,17]. In which, DMT was obtained from PTA in supercritical methanol (at 280–300 °C and 20–40 MPa) [18]. After that, DMT was hydrogenated to dimethyl cyclohexane-1,4-dicarboxylate (DMCD) under harsh conditions (250 °C and 30 MPa H2), and followed hydrogenation of DMCD to CHDM at 250 °C and 38 MPa H2 [19]. Recently, it was reported that waste PET or PET-based products could be utilized as the feedstock for the synthesis of DMT [20,21]. And then, DMT could be hydrogenated to DMCD and CHDM efficiently under mild conditions (see routine (b) in Scheme 1) [22–25]. This technology was safer and more economical which attracted more attention for the upcycling of waste PET. However, the separation and purification of formed DMT from solid catalyst and/or remaining PET are quite difficult since the poor solubility (~1.5 wt% in methanol at 25 °C) and high boiling point of DMT (284 °C) [26,27], and a large amount of poisonous trichloromethane is added to get DMT separated [21]. To overcome this drawback, direct upgrading of PET to DMCD instead of DMT is of great significance [28,29]. As the boiling point of DMCD (~260 °C) is low and its solubility (> 30 wt% in methanol at 25 °C) is high, the formed DMCD can be separated and purified easily compared to DMT [30]. At the same time, it was estimated that the cost of equipment and energy consumption of direct formation of DMCD from waste PET would decrease significantly compared to the traditional two-step conversion route (Tables S1–S3), and the cost of DMCD from one-step routine was about 26% lower than that of the two-step process [31]. But, the coupled methanolysis reaction (of PET to DMT) and hydrogenation reaction (of DMT to DMCD) under mild conditions over a single solid catalyst (see routine (c) in Scheme 1) is quite difficult. Most recently, Mo et al. found that a 0.5Pd5Ni/CeO2 catalyst could give an exceptional yield of DMCD (86.5%) with high selectivity (97.4%) at 180 °C within 10 h (with 0.1 g PET, 0.1 g 0.5Pd5Ni/CeO2, 5 g CH3OH and 6 MPa H2 in feed) [32]. They also found that the production of CHDM via direct conversion of PET to DMCD had higher benefits than traditional routines. In this submission, a defective sulfonated UiO-66def-SO3H was synthesized via replacing partial 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC) with 2-mercaptobenzoic acid (MBA), and the formed UiO-66def-SO3H was further utilized as the support of Ru nanoparticles (NPs). And we hope the mesoporous channels, enlarged surface area and strong acidity of defective sulfonated UiO-66def-SO3H can accelerate the methanolysis step (of waste PET to DMT) and increase the dispersion of Ru, and these combined advantages may further promote its performance in direct upgrading of waste PET to DMCD in one pot. The structure and properties of prepared Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H catalyst were characterized with varied techniques, and its performance in direct upgrading of waste PET to DMCD was discussed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation All materials and chemicals used in this work were addressed in Supporting Information. Defective sulfonated UiO-66def-SO3H was synthesized via solvothermal method according to the published literature in Scheme 2 [33]. At first, 0.700 g ZrCl4, 0.250 g H2BDC and 0.096 g MBA were dissolved in 50 mL N,N′-dimethylformamide (DMF) under vigorous stirring for 30 min. Then, above mixture was transferred to a Teflon-sealed autoclave and reacted at 140 °C for 24 h. Subsequently, the yellow solid (denoted as UiO-66def-SH) was collected via centrifugation, washed with ethanol for five times and dried in vacuum at 80 °C for 12 h. Afterwards, 0.500 g UiO-66def-SH was dispersed in 20 mL ethanol and sulfonated with 10 mL 30 wt% H2O2 (aq) under stirring at room temperature for 12 h. Finally, the white solid (denoted as UiO-66def-SO3H) was obtained using centrifugation, washed with ethanol for five times and dried in vacuum at 80 °C for 12 h. Perfect UiO-66 was synthesized using H2BDC only as ligand in the similar procedure as above, which was described in detail in Supporting Information (Scheme S1). Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H was prepared via impregnation (Scheme S2(a)). Typically, 0.500 g UiO-66def-SO3H was dispersed in 10 mL deionized water and pretreated in ultrasonic bath for 30 min. Then, RuCl3 aqueous solution (2.5 mL, 0.01 g(Ru)·mL–1) was added dropwise to the above mixture. After stirring at room temperature for 8 h, the black solid was collected via evaporating the suspension. At last, the solid was reduced at 170 °C under H2 flow (30 mL·min–1) for 1 h to obtain Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H. Besides, the preparation of Ru/UiO-66 was similar as that of Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H, except replacing UiO-66def-SO3H with UiO-66 (Scheme S2(b)). The structure, composition and properties of defective sulfonated UiO-66def-SO3H and Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H catalyst were characterized using powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES), Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), static water contact angle test, N2 adsorption-desorption measurement, thermogravimetric and differential thermal analysis (TG-DTA), H2 temperature-programmed desorption test (H2-TPD), acid-base titration, pyridine adsorption infrared spectra (pyridine-IR), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), elemental energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS), and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The procedures of these characterization techniques were introduced in Supporting Information in detail. 2.2 Catalyzed reaction Direct upgrading of PET to DMCD was carried out in a stainless-steel autoclave with a Teflon inner layer (50 mL). In a typical run, 0.1 g catalyst, 2.0 g PET, 20 mL methanol and a magnetic stirrer were added to the autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and flushed with purified H2 to remove air thoroughly. Next, the autoclave was pressurized to the desired pressure, and placed in a heating jacket. As being preheated to the required temperature, the stirrer was started at 1000 r·min–1. After reacting for a certain time, the reactor was cooled to room temperature, and the reaction mixture was dissolved with exceed trichloromethane and transferred into a volumetric flask (50 mL). The mixture was spun down and precipitated to separate reaction liquid with remained solid. The products in liquid phase were analyzed using a gas chromatograph (Shimadzu, 14B) equipped with a 30-m capillary column (HP-5MS) and a flame ionization detector and confirmed by gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (Agilent 6890-5973 N), whereas the remained solid was washed with ethanol, dried and weighed to calculate the degradation rate of PET (see Supporting Information). The conversion of PET and yield of DMCD were calculated as follows. Conversion of PET = (1) moleof benzene ring inadded PET - mole of benzene ring in remained PET mole of benzene ring in added PET Yield of DMCD = (2) mole of formed DMCD mole of benzene ring inadded PET × 100 % The performance of the recycled catalyst was examined in the same procedures as above. After the reaction, trichloromethane was added to the reaction mixture to dissolve the products. The leftover catalyst was collected via centrifuged, washed with ethanol, dried at 80 °C in vacuum for 12 h, and weighed before next recycle. The procedures of separated methanolysis of PET and hydrogenation of DMT, coupled methanolysis and hydrogenation of PET in one pot were described in detail in Supporting Information. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization XRD patterns of UiO-66 and UiO-66def-SO3H found that the diffraction patterns of UiO-66 and UiO-66def-SO3H were consistent with those of UiO-66 (Fig. S1) [34], indicating the successful synthesis of UiO-66 and the structure preservation in UiO-66def-SO3H. However, the diffraction intensity of UiO-66def-SO3H decreased slightly compared to that of UiO-66 because of the formation of defects. Meanwhile, two weak diffraction peaks appeared at 2θ = 3°–7° in UiO-66def-SO3H, which were absent in UiO-66. These results implied the formation of clusters [Zr6(OH)4O4] defect along with ligands substitution in UiO-66def-SO3H [33,35]. After the loading of Ru, the characteristic peaks of UiO-66 remained stable in both samples, and lattice parameters (a = b = c) of Ru/UiO-66 (2.07476 nm) and Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H (2.07404 nm) were close to that of UiO-66 (2.07465 nm, Fig. 1 and Table 1 ) [33]. Likewise, the diffraction of clusters [Zr6(OH)4O4] defect (3°–7°) remained in Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H. These results indicated that the introduction of Ru had little influence on the structure of UiO-66 and UiO-66def-SO3H. The content of Ru in Ru/UiO-66 and Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H was 4.79 and 4.87 wt%, respectively (Table 1), but no characteristic peaks of metallic Ru (JCPDS No. 01-070-0274) was detected in either (Fig. 1), inferring the high dispersion of Ru and/or the poor crystallinity of Ru [36]. FTIR analysis found that the strong signals of symmetric and asymmetric stretching vibration of Zr-O in Ru/UiO-66 and Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H nodes appeared at 755 and 670 cm–1, respectively (Fig. S2). Moreover, the typical peaks at 1580, 1500 and 1410 cm–1 were attributed to the stretching vibration of the benzene ring from BDC and/or MBA, and the intensity of bands at 1660 cm–1 belonged to the stretching vibration of C=O in carboxylate [37]. These results confirmed the framework structure of UiO-66 remained stable in both catalysts. As for Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H, the asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibration of O=S=O appeared at 1285 and 1220 cm–1, while the peaks at 1040 and 630 cm–1 corresponded to the stretching vibration of C–S and S–O, respectively [38], which indicated the successful introduction of –SH and the further oxidation to –SO3H (Scheme S3). In addition, the peak at 3440 cm–1 was accredited to the hydroxyl in ligands and/or absorbed water [39]. The hydroxyl peak in Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H was more obvious than that in Ru/UiO-66, inferring that the hydrophilicity of defective sulfonated Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H was stronger owing to extra sulfonic acid groups and the exposure of unsaturated Zr–O nodes [40]. The static water contact angle of Ru/UiO-66 was 37.4°, and this value decreased to 22.9° in Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H (Fig. S3), which was the direct evidence that Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H was more hydrophilic (or less hydrophobic) than Ru/UiO-66. The increasing hydrophilicity of Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H could enhance the adsorption of PET and its oligomers with terminal hydroxyl, as well as promote the desorption of hydrophobic DMT to accelerate the methanolysis of PET [41]. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distributions found that Ru/UiO-66 showed type I isotherms with obvious uptake of N2 at low p/p 0, indicating the domination of micropores (0.79 and 1.17 nm) as similar as UiO-66 (Fig. S4). And the surface area and microporous volume of Ru/UiO-66 (886 m2·g–1 and 0.48 cm3·g–1, Table 2 ) decreased slightly than that of UiO-66 (1012 m2·g–1 and 0.57 cm3·g–1), which implied that Ru NPs mainly located on the surface of UiO-66 (Scheme S2(b)). On the other hand, Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H presented type IV isotherms with a conspicuous hysteresis loop at relative pressure of 0.5–0.9 (Fig. 2 ), suggesting newly emerging mesopores (with the diameters of 2.72 and 3.44 nm) in UiO-66def-SO3H (see Scheme 2). The newly formed mesopores were attributed to that replacing H2BDC with monocarboxylic acid (MBA) resulted in clusters defect as the partial missing of [Zr6(OH)4O4] [42]. Moreover, the surface area and mesoporous volume of Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H reduced obviously from 1148 m2·g–1 and 0.54 cm3·g–1 (of UiO-66 def -SO3H) to 998 m2·g–1 and 0.44 cm3·g–1 (Table 2), respectively, which inferred that Ru NPs mainly located inside mesopores (Scheme S2(a)). The emerging mesopores in Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H would promote the diffusion of waste PET degraded chemicals as well as the contact between reactants and Ru NPs compared to microporous Ru/UiO-66 [43]. Three mass loss stages could be detected during the thermal analysis of Ru/UiO-66 and Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H under N2 flow (Fig. 3 ). At first, the mass loss between 25 and 180 °C might be ascribed to the volatilization of adsorbed solvent and/or water. The second stage from 180 to 400 °C could be attributed to the dehydration of [Zr6O4(OH)4] into [Zr6O6] [44]. After that, a significant mass loss in the range of 400–600 °C was observed owing to the decomposition of ligands (H2BDC and/or MBA) [37]. Finally, the curve altered faintly further raising temperature (> 600 °C). It was noticed that the mass loss at 400–600 °C for Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H (21.5%) was lower than that of Ru/UiO-66 (27.2%) because partial ligands H2BDC was replaced by MBA [32]. The mass loss trend of UiO-66 and UiO-66def-SO3H was similar with that of Ru/UiO-66 and Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H, indicating that the introduction of Ru had almost no effect on the thermal stability of catalysts (Fig. S5). Hydrogen adsorption and activation over Ru/UiO-66 and Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H were checked via H2-TPD (Fig. S6). There was mainly one desorption peak centered at 160–240 °C in both catalysts, which was ascribed to H2 adsorbed on metallic Ru NPs [22]. It was worth noting that the amount of adsorbed H2 over Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H (108.8 μmol·g–1) was higher than that over Ru/UiO-66 (88.7 μmol·g–1), as well as the desorption center temperature (200 °C for Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H while 190 °C for Ru/UiO-66). These results indicated that Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H processed excellent ability for the adsorption and activation of hydrogen, and further inferred that Ru NPs were highly dispersed on defective sulfonated UiO-66def-SO3H (45.1%) than that on UiO-66 (37.4%, Table 1). According to acid-base titration, the acidity of Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H increased obviously from 290 μmol·g–1 (of Ru/UiO-66) to 580 μmol·g–1, owing to the exposure of Zr–O nodes and the introduction of –SO3H (Table S4) [32]. Pyridine-IR spectra of Ru/UiO-66 and Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H exhibited that the typical peaks at 1540 and 1450 cm–1 were corresponding to pyridine adsorbed on Brönsted (Zr–OH and/or –SO3H) and Lewis (Zr–O nodes) acid sites (Fig. 4(a) ). It could be observed that both amounts of Brönsted and Lewis acid sites in Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H (405 and 175 μmol·g–1) increased compared to those of Ru/UiO-66 (190 and 100 μmol·g–1), due to the introduction of –SO3H and clusters defects (Table S4). And the increase of Brönsted acid sites could serve as metal anchoring and promote the dispersion of Ru NPs [45]. The octahedral shaped UiO-66 and UiO-66def-SO3H were clearly observed in SEM analysis (Fig. S7) [32,37]. High-resolution TEM analysis further disclosed that Ru NPs were evenly dispersed in UiO-66def-SO3H with 2.5 nm of the mean size (Figs. 5(a)–(c)), and line-scanning EDS also verified the uniform distribution of Ru NPs (Fig. 5(d) ). Furthermore, the fast Fourier transformation (FFT) analysis of TEM images with the lattice plane intensity profile revealed that the interplanar spacing of metallic Ru (101) was 0.204 nm (Figs. 5 (e) and (f)). On the other hand, it was found that the average size of Ru NPs increased to 3.1 nm in Ru/UiO-66 (Fig. S8). XPS survey of Ru/UiO-66 and Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H found that C 1s spectra of both catalysts showed the carbon peak of C–O (289.2 eV), while additional C–S (287.7 eV) appeared in Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H (Fig. S9(a) and (b)). The overlapped Ru 3d signals were also observed in the range of 280–286 eV (Fig. S9(b)), confirming the introduction of Ru [46,47]. The O 1s spectra of two catalysts displayed three types of oxygen peaks in terms of O–H and/or S–O (533.1 eV), C–O and/or S=O (531.7 eV), and Zr–O (530.3 eV, Fig. S9(c)) [33]. Besides, the existence of S could be confirmed by S 2p 1/2 (169.4 eV) and S 2p 3/2 (168.2 eV) in Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H, which was absent in Ru/UiO-66 (Fig. S9(d)) [33]. Additionally, it was interesting to find that the binding energies of Zr 3d 3/2 and Zr 3d 5/2 located at 184.9 and 182.6 eV in Ru/UiO-66, and negatively shifted to 184.5 and 182.2 eV in Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H (Fig. S10) [36], which might be accredited to the electrons transfer from Ru NPs to unsaturated Zr–O nodes in defective clusters. The binding energy of Ru 3p in Ru/UiO-66 could be deconvoluted into two pairs of double peaks, the pair peaks at 462.1 eV (3p 3/2) and 484.2 eV (3p 1/2) were assigned to Ru0 (metallic Ru), while the other at 465.1 eV (3p 3/2) and 487.8 eV (3p 1/2) might be attributed to Ru δ+ (RuO x ) in Fig. 4(b) [22,48]. Significantly, the pair peaks of Ru0 increased to 462.7 eV (3p 3/2) and 484.8 eV (3p 1/2), meanwhile, the other assigned to Ru δ+ shifted positively to 465.7 eV (3p 3/2) and 488.4 eV (3p 1/2) in Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H. The positive shift testified that more Ru species might be anchored in Zr–O nodes to form Ru–O–Zr and/or the electrons transferred from Ru to Zr–O in Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H than Ru/UiO-66 [48]. Besides, surface Ru content of Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H (4.69%) was lower than that of Ru/UiO-66 (6.13%). These results might be attributed to that the size of Ru NPs in UiO-66def-SO3H (2.5 nm) was smaller than that of Ru/UiO-66 (3.1 nm, Table 1) and/or more Ru NPs would locate in mesoporous channels of Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H (Fig. S2(a)) as Ru NPs contacted strongly with defective sulfonated UiO-66def-SO3H than pristine UiO-66 [22]. 3.2 Catalytic performance Scheme S4 showed the successive pathway for the coupled methanolysis (of PET to DMT) and hydrogenation (of DMT to DMCD). At first, 2-hydroxyethyl methyl terephthalate (MHET) could be detected as an intermediate in the methanolysis of PET. And then, DMT formed after the further methanolysis of MHET [21]. Afterwards, DMCD was the target product via the hydrogenation of benzene ring in DMT, with a byproduct, methyl 4-methylbenzoate (MMB), might form via the hydrogenation of an ester group [24]. Fig. 6(a) exhibited the performance of Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H for the separated methanolysis of PET (without the addition of H2) under varied reaction temperatures. It was found that the conversion of PET increased quickly from 16.8% to 100% as the temperature raised from 130 to 160 °C (the TOF of each acid site reached 15.1 h–1 at 130 °C), with the yield of DMT also increased sharply from 16.8% to 94.5%. Further increasing the temperature to 170 and 180 °C, the conversion of PET remained 100% and the yield of DMT enhanced slightly to 97%. Meanwhile, increasing temperature could reduce the yield of MHET (from 3.4% at 130 °C to 1.5% at 180 °C) and promote its further methanolysis to DMT. Compared to that of Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H, the catalytic activity of Ru/UiO-66 was suppressed under the same condition in Fig. 6(b) . When the reaction temperature was raised from 130 to 180 °C, the conversion of PET merely grew from 2.9% to 66.7% (the TOF of each acid site was only 5.2 h–1 at 130 °C), while the yield of DMT rose from 0.8% to 62.1%. The yield of MHET increased at first from 1.2% (130 °C) to its maximum of 5.3% at 160 °C, and then decreased to 1.9% (180 °C). The performance of Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H for separated methanolysis of PET under varied reaction times (Fig. S11), different ratios between methanol and PET (Fig. S12) and catalyst dosages (Fig. S13) was described and discussed in Supporting Information. These results confirmed that Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H was active for the methanolysis of PET to DMT, and the highest yield of DMT reached 96.8% over 170 °C and 2 h. The performance of UiO-66def-SO3H, Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H, UiO-66, Ru/UiO-66 and without catalyst for the methanolysis of PET to DMT at 150 °C for 2 h was compared in Table S5. It was found that the introduction of –SO3H could enhance the yield of DMT obviously due to the increased acidity (see Table S4). While the conversion of PET and yield of DMT decreased slightly after the loading of Ru NPs, which might be attributed to that some acid sites and pores were blocked by the introduction of Ru. And the degradation rate of PET without catalyst was less than 1%, indicating the essential of catalysts. Fig. 7(a) displayed the performance of Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H for the separated hydrogenation of DMT under varied reaction temperatures. The conversion of DMT and yield of DMCD increased promptly from 20.2% to 97.4% and 18.5% to 95.7%, respectively, when the temperature was raised from 120 to 160 °C (the TOF of each Ru reached 47.9 h–1 at 120 °C). As the temperature further increased to 170 °C, the conversion of DMT remained ~98% with high yield of DMCD (96.5%). And, the yield of MMB was below 1.5% at all temperatures. On the other hand, the performance of Ru/UiO-66 as catalyst was poor as the conversion of DMT just grew from 8.5% to 81.6% with the temperature rising from 120 to 170 °C (the TOF of each Ru was only 24.7 h–1 at 120 °C), and the highest yield of DMCD only reached 79.3% at 170 °C in Fig. 7(b) . Simultaneously, the yield of MMB was higher than 2.2% in these experiments. The performance of Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H for separated hydrogenation of DMT to DMCD under varied reaction times (Fig. S14), hydrogen pressures (Fig. S15) and catalyst dosages (Fig. S16) was presented in Supporting Information. It was confirmed that Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H was also effective for the hydrogenation of DMT to DMCD, and the best yield of DMCD reached 96.5% under 170 °C and 3 MPa H2 within 2 h. To verify the performance of Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H for the coupled methanolysis and hydrogenation in one pot, the reaction mixture and catalyst after first-step methanolysis of PET at 160 °C for 2 h was directly used as the feedstock of second-step hydrogenation for another 2 h at 160 °C (Table S6). It was found that PET converted completely and the yield of DMCD reached 94.3%, which was close to separated methanolysis and hydrogenation (Figs. 6(a) and 7(a)). On the other hand, the conversion of PET and yield of DMCD were just 89.2% and 11.9% over Ru/UiO-66. Encouraged by the excellent performance in above one-pot consecutive methanolysis and hydrogenation, Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H was utilized for direct upgrading of PET to DMCD at 160 °C and 3 MPa H2, and the results were shown in Fig. 8(a) . It was found that DMT was the main intermediate at the beginning of the reaction (0–6 h) and the yield of DMCD increased gradually, indicating the stepwise conversion of PET to DMCD via DMT. When the reaction time was prolonged to 8 h, the yield of DMCD reached 77.8% (with the yield of DMT decreasing to 18.9%) and PET converted completely. Moreover, the yield of DMCD further increased to 97.4% accompanied with 0.7%, 0.3% and 1.2% content of DMT, MHET and MMB as the reaction time was extended to 12 h. In comparison, the yield of DMCD was only 17.6% with 62.9% amount of DMT under 88.4% conversion of PET within 8 h over Ru/UiO-66 in Fig. 8(b). In order to shorten the reaction time, direct upgrading of PET to DMCD was performed at 170 °C and these results were shown in Fig. 9(a) . It was quite interesting to note that the conversion of PET reached 78.7% within 2 h, and the yield of DMT and DMCD enhanced to 63.8% and 10.4%, respectively. When the reaction time was prolonged to 4 and 5 h, the yield of DMCD increased quickly to 56.5% and 96.2% with the yield of DMT dropping to 39.7% and 1.3% under complete conversion of PET. Moreover, the yield of DMCD further reached 97.7% accompanied with 0.9% content of DMT when the reaction time was extended to 6 h. These results indicated that increasing the temperature from 160 to 170 °C could effectively accelerate direct upgrading from PET to DMCD. The reusability of Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H in direct upgrading of PET to DMCD at 170 °C within 4 h was manifested in Fig. 9(b). It was of great significance to note that Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H was quite stable in five recycles. The detected conversion of PET remained 100% in all cycles, and the yield of DMCD decreased slightly from 56.5% (in first usage) to 53.5% (in fifth usage), while the yield of DMT increased slightly from 39.7% to 42.5%. Spent Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H was characterized and compared to the fresh one (Figs. S17–S20 and Tables S7, S8). It was found that the spent catalyst remained the UiO-66 skeleton with defects and cell parameters, and the characteristic peaks of metallic Ru still disappeared (Fig. S17 and Table S7). Furthermore, the spent Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H also showed type IV isotherms with a hysteresis loop at relative pressure ranging from 0.5 to 0.9, and the pore size distributions were similar with that of fresh one (Fig. S18 and Table S8). Besides, the chemical states of Ru species were similar as that of fresh catalyst, while Ru NPs kept well-anchored without obvious leaching (Fig. S19 and Table S7). And, the spent Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H maintained the morphology of regular octahedron resembled the fresh one, and there was no obvious agglomeration of Ru NPs (Fig. S20). These results indicated that the mesoporous structure and uniformly dispersed Ru NPs in Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H remained stable during the reaction. At the same time, waste beverage bottles, packaging film and textile fiber were also used as feedstocks (Fig. S21) for direct upgrading of PET to DMCD over Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H, and these results were summarized in Table 3 . The yields of DMCD were higher than 92% with complete conversions of PET at 170 °C and 3 MPa H2 within 6 h for three PET-based products, which indicated that Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H had potential in the application for the upcycling of various waste PET-based feedstocks. 3.3 Catalyst structure-performance relationship Direct formation of DMCD via waste PET can avoid the difficult and expensive separation process of DMT from solid catalyst and/or remaining PET, but the efficient catalyst should be versatile as it must contain both acid sites (for the methanolysis of PET) and Ru NPs (for the hydrogenation of DMT, see Scheme S4). In this work, the special designed Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H possesses abundant acidity (580 μmol·g–1, see Table S4), mesoporous channels (2.72 and 3.44 nm), high surface area and pore volume (998 m2·g–1 and 0.83 cm3·g–1, Fig. 2 and Table 2). These properties make Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H exhibit excellent performance for the first-step methanolysis of PET to DMT. The calculated TOF of each acid site in Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H reached 15.1 h–1 at 130 °C, and this activity was higher than that of Ru/UiO-66 (only 5.2 h–1 at 130 °C, Fig. 6). At the same time, high hydrophilicity and strong acidity of -SO3H can also make the methanolysis of PET to DMT over Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H catalyst accelerated among those reported solid catalyst including Cu/SiO2-IM, Cu/ZrO2, Ti0.5Si0.5O2, calcined Na2SiO3 and MgO/NaY (Table S9). Besides, unsaturated Zr–O nodes and –SO3H can anchor Ru, and the dispersion of Ru in Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H reaches 45.1% (see Table 1), which is beneficial for the adsorption (108.8 μmol·g–1) and activation of hydrogen (Fig. S6), further accelerates the hydrogenation of DMT [22]. The positive shift of Ru species in Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H also testifies the active electron interactions between Ru to Zr–O (Fig. 4(b)), enhancing the hydrogenation ability of Ru. Meanwhile, the mesoporous channels (2.72 and 3.44 nm) and enlarged pore volume (0.83 cm3·g–1) in Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H can promote the diffusion of substance and the contact between reactants and Ru NPs (Fig. 2, Table 2 and Scheme S2) [43]. In addition, sufficient acidity makes the benzene ring absorbed via “non-coplanar” on Ru species and promote the selective hydrogenation of benzene ring (see Table S4) [49,50]. The calculated TOF of Ru in Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H reached 47.9 h–1 at 120 °C, which was higher than that of Ru/UiO-66 (only 24.7 h–1 at 120 °C, Fig. 7). These properties make Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H show higher performance in the hydrogenation of DMT to DMCD compared to those reference Ru-based catalysts including Ru4Pt2/Al2O3, Ru0.4Ni2/CNT, Ru/Ni/Ni(Al)O x , Ru/SBA-15 and Ru/HZSM-5 (see Table S10). On the other hand, the reaction energy barrier diagram for the hydrogenation of benzene ring (DMT) to cyclohexyl (DMCD) over Ru was displayed in Fig. S22 [51,52]. As the relative energy of cyclohexyl (–4.78 eV) was lower than that of benzene ring (0.00 eV), density functional theory (DFT) calculations suggested that Ru cluster was efficient for the hydrogenation of benzene ring (DMT) to cyclohexyl (DMCD) via sequential hydrogenation following the Horiuti-Polanyi type mechanism (Fig. S23 and Table S11) [53,54]. These characteristics of Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H indicates that Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H simultaneously possesses enlarged pore channels (mesopores and high pore volume), abundant acidity and hydrophilicity (unsaturated Zr–O nodes and –SO3H), sufficient hydrogenation active sites (highly dispersed Ru NPs), which confirms the versatility and high efficiency for the methanolysis of PET (Fig. 6(a)) and hydrogenation of DMT (Fig. 7(a)), realizing direct upgrading of PET to DMCD in one pot (Figs. 8(a) and 9(a)). Furthermore, Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H also possesses the outstanding chemical and thermal stability (Fig. 9(b)), which can be ascribed to abundant acid sites (see Table S4), strong interaction between Ru species and UiO-66def-SO3H (Fig. S19), as well as mesoporous channels to support Ru NPs (Fig. S18 and Table S8), avoiding the aggregation and leaching of Ru NPs during the reaction (Fig. S17, Fig. S20 and Table S7). That is, the special designed Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H integrating the active sites for the methanolysis of PET and hydrogenation of DMT achieves direct upgrading of PET to DMCD in one pot with excellent activity and stability. 3.4 Possible reaction kinetics and mechanism According to above experiments, the possible reaction kinetics of methanolysis of PET, hydrogenation of DMT, direct upgrading of PET to DMCD over Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H was analyzed to further reveal the reaction mechanism. Based on the separated performance of methanolysis of PET to DMT over Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H (Fig. S11), it was found that the methanolysis of PET was approximate first-order reaction of remaining concentration of PET (Fig. S24) [55,56], and the calculated apparent rate constant (at 150 °C) was about 0.7667 h–1. On the other hand, the rate of separated hydrogenation of DMT over Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H (Fig. S14) was unattached with the remaining concentration of DMT in the reaction mixture (Fig. S25), and the calculated apparent rate constant (at 130 °C) was about 0.1192 molDMT·L–1·h–1. In the direct upgrading of PET to DMCD over Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H, the calculated rate constant of consuming PET at 160 °C was 0.4926 h–1 (Figs. 8(a) and S26), and it increased obviously to 0.7732 h–1 at 170 °C (Figs. 9(a) and S27). These results indicated that the direct upgrading of PET to DMCD over Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H was difficult, and the consuming rate of PET depended strongly on reaction temperature. At the same time, it was found that the selectivity of MHET (intermediate product of DMT, see Scheme S4) decreased continuously from 3.9% (1 h) to 0.2% (6 h) during the direct conversion of PET to DMCD (Fig. 9(a)), indicating that MHET formed at the beginning of the reaction and could further convert to DMT (Scheme S4 and Fig. S11). Moreover, the selectivity of DMT first rose to 81.1% (2 h) and then declined to 0.9% (6 h) with the increasing formation of DMCD. These results indicated that the formation DMT from PET and/or MHET proceeded quickly than the followed hydrogenation of DMT to DMCD. In addition, the selectivity of MMB (the byproduct of the hydrogenation of ester group in DMT) increased slightly to 1.4% (6 h) due to the methylation under long reaction time. According to the above results and related literatures, we think that the overall reaction paths over Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H should be carried out in the following steps. At first, acid sites (including Zr–O nodes, Zr–OH and –SO3H) on Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H interacted with the carbonyl oxygen in PET, while the carbonyl carbon was attacked by the nucleophilic hydroxyl in methanol, resulting in chain cleavage and modification of the ester group. In this process, DMT was the main product via methanol transesterification on both sides, and there was also small amount of MHET formed via methanol transesterification at one side (or by transesterification of ethylene glycol with DMT [57]), which could further convert to DMT. Then, the delocalized π conjugated band of benzene ring in DMT was activated on Ru sites, and further the activated hydrogen, which was adsorbed and dissociated on Ru, attacked the delocalized π conjugated band, and the benzene ring was gradually hydrogenated to generate the cyclohexyl (DMCD). Due to the methylation, part of DMCD was converted into MMB especially at high reaction temperature and H2 pressure for long reaction time. 4 Conclusions In summary, defective sulfonated UiO-66def-SO3H was synthesized via defect engineering and sulfonation of UiO-66, and Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H catalyst could be prepared via impregnation of RuCl3 and reduction. Characterization indicated that the mesoporous Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H possessed enlarged surface area and pore volume, enhanced acid sites, and high dispersion of Ru than those of Ru/UiO-66. As a result, Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H not only showed prominent performance in separated methanolysis of PET to DMT and hydrogenation of DMT to DMCD, but also processed potential for direct upgrading of PET to DMCD under mild condition. PET could be converted completely and the yield of DMCD reached 97.7% at 170 °C and 3 MPa H2 within 6 h. It was concluded that Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H combining the newly emerging mesopores, abundant acidity (active sites of methanolysis), high dispersion of Ru (active sites of hydrogenation) and hydrophilic sites (adsorption of PET and its oligomers) was efficient for direct conversion of PET to DMCD. And, Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H remained stable after five cycles due to the strong interaction between Ru NPs and Zr–O nodes, and the mesopores for loading Ru NPs. Moreover, Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H was also versatile for the upgrading of varied PET-based products including beverage bottles, packaging film and textile fiber. coredata.dc:description: Poly(ethylene glycol-co-1,4-cyclohexanedimethanol terephthalate) (PETG) possesses excellent properties and stability than traditional poly(ethylene terephthalate) (PET). However, the production and application of PETG are restricted by the expensive monomer (1,4-cyclohexanedimethanol, CHDM). Direct upgrading of waste PET to dimethyl cyclohexane-1,4-dicarboxylate (DMCD) can promote the production of CHDM in large scale. In this work, a bifunctional Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H catalyst was synthesized and utilized in coupled methanolysis (of waste PET to dimethyl terephthalate (DMT)) and hydrogenation (of DMT to DMCD) under mild condition. Characterizations revealed that Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H possessed mesopores (dominant channels of 2.72 and 3.44 nm), enlarged surface area (998 m2·g–1), enhanced acidity (580 μmol·g–1), and Ru nanoparticles (NPs) dispersed highly (45.1%) compared to those of Ru/UiO-66. These combined advantages could accelerate the methanolysis and hydrogenation reactions simultaneously, promoting the performance of direct upgrading of PET to DMCD in one pot. In particular, the conversion of PET and yield of DMCD over Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H reached 100% and 97.7% at 170 °C and 3 MPa H2 within 6 h. Moreover, Ru/UiO-66def-SO3H was also capable for the upcycling of waste PET-based products including beverage bottles, textile fiber and packaging film to DMCD.
